In France, voting is traditionally a low-tech experience: the voters isolate themselves in a booth and stick a pre-printed ballot paper, on which the candidate of their choice is listed, into an envelope.

The French electoral law lays down the procedure quite strictly.

Since 1988, ballot boxes must be transparent so that voters and observers can verify that no ballot papers have been tampered with at the start of the election and that no ballot papers are added, except those of the legitimately counted and authorised voters.

When a small group of living things (a small population) is separated from the main population, from which it originates (e.g., if they move over a mountain range or across a river, so that they cannot easily return), they often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so that the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor, rather than what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all. It still needs the same adjustments as before.
As time goes by, the new population begins to adapt to its new environment, and then it looks less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years two populations look so different that they can no longer be assigned to the same species.
We call this process speciation, which simply means the emergence of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from the technological push or the technological imperative to the strict sense that human destiny is determined by a logic that is linked to scientific laws and its manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general views. One, that the development of technology follows a path that is largely outside of cultural or political influence, and two, that technology itself has effects on societies that are more inherent than socially determined.
One could say that the automobile is unavoidably linked to the development of roads.
However, a nationwide road network for only a small number of cars is not economically viable. Therefore, new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of car ownership.

The widespread ownership of automobiles also leads to a higher number of accidents on the roads, which in turn leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to repair damaged bodies.

The use of ships for the transport of goods is by far the most efficient method of transporting large numbers of people and goods across the oceans.
The task of the navy has traditionally been to ensure that a country is able to transport people and goods, and at the same time to hinder the enemy's ability to transport people and goods.
One of the most recent examples of this is the North Atlantic Campaign in World War II. The Americans tried to bring manpower and material across the Atlantic to help Britain.
At the same time, the German Navy tried to stop this traffic mainly with submarines.
If the Allies had failed, Germany would probably have conquered Britain just as it had conquered the rest of Europe.
Goats were apparently already domesticated in the Zagros Mountains in Iran about 10,000 years ago.
Ancient cultures and peoples began to keep animals as pets for their milk, fur, meat, and skin.

House goats were normally kept in herds that grazed on hills or other pastures. They were tended by shepherds, just like the more familiar sheep shepherds; often these were children or adolescents. These grazing methods are still used today.
Even in the 16th century, England had built railway sidings.

Although the trolley lines were made of parallel wooden planks, they allowed the horses pulling the wagons to reach higher speeds and to pull heavier loads than on the somewhat rougher roads of the time.
Early on, wooden sleepers were introduced to secure the position of the rails. However, it was soon realized that rails made of a band of iron are more efficient.
This became common, but the iron caused more wear on the wooden wheels of the wagons.
Finally, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first fully iron rails were introduced.
The first known form of locomotion was walking. Humans began to walk upright about two million years ago with the emergence of Homo erectus (which means "upright man").
Their predecessors, the Australopithecus, did not walk upright as regularly.
Two-footed species are found in Australopithecus fossils from 4.2 to 3.9 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus may have already walked on two feet seven million years ago.

After his farewell by Congress on July 4, a handwritten, signed by John Hancock and Charles Thomson, the president and secretary of Congress, was sent a few blocks away to the printing shop of John Dunlap.
During the night between 150 and 200 copies were made, which are now known as „Dunlap broadsides“.
The first public reading of the document was given by John Nixon in the Independence Hall courtyard on July 8.
One was sent to George Washington on July 6, which he read to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy reached London on August 10.
Of the 25 Dunlap broadsides that still exist, they are the oldest surviving copies of the document. The original handwritten document has not survived the ages.

Many do not see them as dinosaurs because they have feathers and can fly.
But many things about birds still look like a dinosaur.
They have feet with scales and claws, lay eggs and walk on two hind legs like a Tyrannosaurus rex.
Nearly all computers used today are based on the processing of information that is encoded in binary form.
A binary number can only have one of two values, either 0 or 1, and these numbers are called binary digits, or bits, in computer jargon.

The best sign of poisoning by swallowing is the presence of an open container with medicines or poisonous household chemicals.
Check the label for specific first aid instructions for this particular poison.

This term derives from the ancient familiarity with bedbugs. These are insects which are very adaptable at parasitizing humans.
Both bedbugs and cockroaches are nidicol, i.e. adapted to living in the nest or home of their hosts.
In the United States of America there are approximately 400,000 known cases of multiple sclerosis (MS), which makes it the most common neurological disease in adults of younger and middle age.
MS is a disease that affects the central nervous system, which is made up of the brain, the spinal cord and the optic nerve.
Studies have shown that the risk of MS is twice as high in women as in men.

Behavioural patterns that are not only reactions to signals from external cycles are known from many organisms, including bacteria, fungi, plants and animals.
Biological clocks are self-sustaining oscillators that even in the absence of external signals can execute swinging cycles for a certain amount of time.
The Hershey-Chase experiment was one of the key pieces of evidence that DNA is a genetic material.
Hershey and Chase used phages or viruses to insert their own DNA into a bacterium.
They took two experiments, in which they either marked the DNA of the phage with radioactive phosphorus or a protein in the phage with radioactive sulfur.
Mutations can have different effects, depending on what kind of mutation it is, what significance the affected piece of genetic material has, and whether the affected cells are germ cells.
Only mutations in germ cells can be passed on to children, while mutations elsewhere lead to cell death or cancer.

Examples of activities on site are hunting, fishing, photography, bird watching, visiting parks and learning about the ecosystem.

Every morning people leave small provincial towns in their cars to go to their workplace and are passed by other people who have just left their workplace in the town they just left.
In this dynamic pendulum traffic, everyone is in some way connected to a transport system that is based on the private car, and supports it.
Science now points out that this massive carbon economy has taken us out of one of the stable states that has supported human evolution over the last two million years.
Everyone participates in society and uses transport systems. Almost everyone complains about the transport systems.
In developed countries you rarely hear as many complaints about the water quality or the collapse of bridges.
Why do transport systems lead to such problems, why do they fail daily? Are transport engineers simply incompetent, or is something more fundamental going on?
Traffic flow is the study of the movement of individual drivers and vehicles between two points and the interactions that take place between them.
Unfortunately, it's hard to study traffic flows, because you can't predict driver behaviour with 100% certainty.
Fortunately, drivers tend to behave consistently; therefore, traffic flows have a certain consistency and can be roughly described mathematically.
To better illustrate the traffic flow, the relationships between the three most important properties were defined: (1) flow, (2) density and (3) speed.
These relationships help with the planning, design and operation of facilities at the roadside.

Most insects can fold their wings along their body.
This allows them to have a wider choice of small hiding places, where they can hide from predators.
Today, dragonflies and mayflies are the only insects that cannot fold their wings back.

The Amazon is the second longest and the most water-rich river in the world. It carries more than eight times as much water as the second largest river.
The Amazon is also the widest river in the world, in places up to six miles wide.
Over 20 percent of the water that flows into the oceans comes from the Amazon.
The Amazon River is 6,387 km (3,980 miles) long. It takes water from thousands of smaller rivers.

Informational theories concentrate on finding what moves or appeals to people.
These theories suggest that people have certain needs and/or desires that are internalized as they mature.
These theories deal with what makes certain people want to do exactly what they do, and what influences in their environment cause them to do certain things or not to do them.
Two popular content theories are Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs and Herzberg's Two-Factor Theory.
In general, two behavioral patterns can emerge when managers begin to lead their former colleagues. At one end of the spectrum is the attempt to remain "one of the guys" (or one of the girls).
This type of manager has problems making unpopular decisions, enforcing disciplinary measures, assessing performance, assigning responsibilities and taking on employees.
At the other end of the spectrum, one becomes an unrecognizable individual who has to do everything differently than the team did and takes everything for themselves.
In the end, the team manager is responsible for the success and failure of the team.
This behavior often leads to conflicts between the leaders and the rest of the team.
Virtual teams are managed to the same high standards as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
Virtual team members often have the function of a contact point for their immediate physical group.
They often have more autonomy than traditional team members, as their teams meet in different time zones that may not be considered by the local leadership.
The presence of a real "invisible team" (Larson and LaFasto 1989, p. 109) is also a unique component of a virtual team.
"The ""invisible team"" is the leadership team, to whom each member reports. The invisible team sets the standards for each member."

When all available resources are used effectively across all departments of an organization, creativity and innovation can emerge.

Neurobiological data provide physical evidence for a theoretical approach to the study of cognition. Thus they limit the research area and make it much more precise.
The correlation between brain pathology and behavior supports scientists in their research.
It has been known for a long time that different types of brain damage, such as trauma, injury, and tumors, can influence behavior and cause changes in certain brain functions.
New technologies enable us to see and study certain brain structures and processes for the first time.
It gives us a lot of information and materials to build simulation models that help us understand the processes in our head.

KI (Künstliche Intelligenz) is often associated with Science Fiction, but is an important branch of computer science that deals with behavior, learning and the adaptation of machines to intelligent behavior.
Research in the field of AI covers the creation of machines to automate tasks that require intelligent behaviour.
Examples of this are controlling, setting up strategies and time plans, the ability to answer customer questions and diagnoses, as well as handwriting, voice and face recognition.
Such things have become independent disciplines that concentrate on finding solutions to real-life problems.

Today, KI systems are widely used in the fields of business, medicine, engineering and the military, and have also been incorporated into numerous software applications for home computers and video games.
Excursions are an important part of every school class. Not infrequently a teacher would like to take her pupils to places that cannot be reached by bus.
Virtual excursions are a technological solution. Students can view museum exhibits, visit an aquarium, or admire beautiful works of art from the classroom.
Sharing a virtual field trip is also a great way to reflect on a trip and share experiences with future classes.

For example, students at the Bennet School in North Carolina design a website every year about their trip to the state capital. The website is redesigned every year, but the previous versions remain online and serve as a scrapbook.

Blogs can also help to improve the writing skills of students. Although students at the beginning of their blogging experience often have a sloppy grammar and spelling, this usually changes when there is an audience.
As students are often a very critical audience, the blog author makes an effort to improve his writing style to avoid criticism.
Blogging "forces the students to learn more about the world around them." The need to inspire interest in the audience inspires the students to write intelligently and interestingly (Toto, 2004).
Blogging is a tool that inspires collaboration and encourages students to continue learning outside the traditional school day.

The appropriate use of blogs can enable students to become more analytical and critical; through the active reaction to Internet materials, students can define their positions in the context of the texts of others and to express their own perspectives on certain topics.
Ottawa is Canada's enchanting, bilingual capital and is distinguished by a number of art galleries and museums that present Canada's past and present.
Further south are the Niagara Falls, and to the north the unspoilt beauty of nature in Muskoka and beyond.
All these things and others make Ontario typical of what is considered typical Canadian by outsiders.
Large areas further north are sparsely populated and some are almost uninhabited wilderness.
A population comparison that surprised many: More African Americans live in the United States than Canadian citizens.
The islands of East Africa are located in the Indian Ocean off the east coast of Africa.
Madagascar is by far the largest and, as far as the animal kingdom is concerned, a separate continent.
Most of the smaller islands are independent nations or belong to France and are known as luxurious seaside resorts.
The Arabs also brought Islam into the country, and on the Comoros and Mayotte it was very successful.
The European influence and colonialism began in the 15th century, when the Portuguese seafarer Vasco da Gama discovered the Cape route from Europe to India.
The region is bounded to the north by the Sahel zone and to the south and west by the Atlantic Ocean.

The present-day Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BCE and was used by the Phoenicians, the Romans and the Merinids as a strategic port under the name Anfa.
The Portuguese destroyed them and rebuilt them under the name Casa Branca, only to abandon them after an earthquake in 1755.
The Moroccan Sultan rebuilt the city as Dar el Beida and it was named Casablanca by Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places to shop in all of Morocco.

Around the old Medina, it is easy to find places where traditional Moroccan wares such as tagines, ceramics, leather goods, water pipes, and a whole range of tinnef are sold, but that is only for tourists.
Goma is a tourist town of the Democratic Republic of the Congo in the extreme east near Rwanda.
In 2002 Goma was destroyed by the lava of the Nyiragongo volcano, which buried most of the city's streets, especially the city centre.
While Goma is relatively safe, every stay outside of Goma should be carefully planned in order to learn about the ongoing fighting in the province of North Kivu.
The city is also the starting point for climbing the volcano Nyiragongo as well as for some of the cheapest gorilla tracking tours in Africa.
You can use bodabodas (motorcycle taxis) to go around Goma. The usual (local) price is ~500 Congolese Francs for the short ride.
The combination of its relative inaccessibility has made "Timbuktu" a metaphor for exotic, distant countries.
Although Timbuktu is known as a tourist attraction and has an airport, it is today a poor town.
In 1990 it was added to the list of endangered world cultural heritage sites due to the threat of desertification.
It was one of the most important stops on Louis Gates' PBS special "Wonders of the African World."
The city stands in stark contrast to the rest of the cities in the country, because it has more of an Arabic than an African flair.
The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in the northeast of South Africa. It borders in the east on Mozambique, in the north on Zimbabwe and in the south on the Crocodile River.
The park has an area of 19,500 km2 and is divided into 14 different ecosystems, each of which supports a different animal population.
It is one of the main attractions of South Africa and is regarded as the flagship of the South African National Parks (SANParks).
Like all South African national parks, the park charges daily entrance fees.
It may also be worth buying a Wild Card, which gives access either to selected parks in South Africa or to all South African national parks.
Hong Kong Island is the name-giver for the territory of Hong Kong and stands at the centre of many tourists' plans.
The buildings that make up the Hong Kong skyline were compared to a shimmering diagram of a balcony, visible through the presence of the waters of Victoria Harbour.
For the best chances of Hong Kong you should leave the island and go to the opposite shore of Kowloon.
The majority of the urbanization of Hong Kong Island is densely packed along the northern coastline of newly reclaimed land.
This is the place where the British colonists took over. If you are looking for traces of the colonial past of the area, this is a good starting point.
The Sundarbans are the largest mangrove forest in the world and stretch 80 km from the Bangladeshi and Indian hinterland to the coast.
The Sundarbans were designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest within the Indian state is called the Sundarbans National Park.
The forests are not only mangrove swamps – they also include some of the last remaining stands of the mighty jungle that once covered the Ganges plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km2, of which a third is covered by water and marshes.
The Sundarbans are a natural reserve since 1966, and according to estimates there are now 400 Bengal tigers and about 30,000 spotted deer living there.
Buses run all day long from the inter-district bus station (on the other side of the river), with most buses, especially those going to the east and Jakar/Bumthang, leaving between 06:30 and 07:30.
As the buses between the districts are often full, it is advisable to buy a ticket a few days in advance.
Most districts are traversed by small Japanese buses, which are comfortable and stable.
Taxi services offer a quick and convenient way to get to nearby places such as Paro (150 km) and Punakha (200 km).
The Oyapock River Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River and connects the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges de l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
Their two towers are 83 meters high, their length is 378 meters and they have two lanes with a width of 3.50 meters.
The clearance under the bridge is 15 meters. The construction work was completed in August 2011, but the opening for traffic was not until March 2017.
The bridge is expected to be fully operational in September 2017. It is hoped that the Brazilian customs posts will be completed by then.
The Guaraní were the most important indigenous group that inhabited the eastern part of Paraguay. They lived as semi-nomadic hunters who also practiced subsistence agriculture.
The Chaco region was also the home of other groups of indigenous tribes, such as the Guaycurú and the Payaguá, who survived by hunting, gathering and fishing.
Paraguay, formerly known as the Great Province of the West Indies, was created in the 16th century as a result of the meeting of the Spanish conquerors with the indigenous groups.
The Spaniards began the colonisation period which lasted three centuries.
Since the foundation of Asunción in 1537, Paraguay has been able to preserve much of its indigenous character and identity.
Argentina is known for having the best polo team and players in the world.
The biggest tournament of the year takes place in December on Las Cañitas polo fields.
Smaller tournaments and competitions can also be viewed at other times of the year.
Information about competitions and sales points for polo tickets can be found at the Argentine Polo Association.
The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Pound (FKP), which is pegged to the value of the British Pound (GBP).
Money can be exchanged in the only bank on the island, which is located opposite the FIC West Store in Stanley.
The British pound is generally accepted everywhere on the islands and at Stanley-credit cards. US dollars are often accepted.

Credit cards are unlikely to be accepted on the more remote islands, although British and US currency may be accepted; it's best to check with the owners beforehand to find out what payment methods they accept.
It is almost impossible to exchange the currency of the Falkland Islands outside the islands themselves, so you should exchange your money before you leave the islands.
Because Montevideo is south of the equator, it is summer there when it is winter in the northern hemisphere and vice versa.
Montevideo is in the subtropics. In the summer months, temperatures over +30 °C are usual.
Winter can be deceptively cool: The temperatures rarely go below freezing, but wind and humidity make it feel colder than the thermometer indicates.
There is no distinct rainy or dry season: The amount of rainfall remains more or less the same throughout the year.
Although many of the animals in the park are used to seeing people, the wild animals are still wild and should not be fed or disturbed.
According to the park regulations, visitors must keep at least 100 yards (30 m) from bears and wolves and 25 yards (7.5 m) from all other wild animals!
No matter how peaceful Bison, Wapitis, Elk, Bears and practically all large animals may seem, they can still attack.
Every year, dozens of visitors are injured because they don't give the animals enough space. These animals are large, wild, and possibly dangerous, so give them enough room.

Apia is the capital of Samoa on the island of Upolu and has a population of just under 40,000.

The beaches of North Shore (in the North Harbour district) lie on the Pacific Ocean and stretch from Long Bay in the north to Devonport in the south.
Most are sandy beaches with safe swimming and most provide shade from the Pohutukawa trees.
The beaches of Tamaki Drive are located at Waitemata Harbour, in the affluent suburbs of Mission Bay and St. Heliers in Central Auckland.
There are family beaches that sometimes overflow, with a beautiful shopping promenade along the coast. Swimming here is safe.

Travel agencies usually offer packages that include breakfast, transport to and from the airport or even a combination of flight and hotel.

The term safari in everyday use refers to a land trip to observe the overwhelming African wildlife, especially in the savannah.

A foot safari (also called: bushwalk, walking safari or footing) is a walk that lasts either a few hours or several days.
